Again, apologies if this is a doubled-up message...

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> Great paper. Easy to read, good content. It seems so obvious once 
you
> spell it out.

Thanks, Chad.

> I did have a question about one table:
> 
> Type Avg. minutes perrun
> (rounded to nearestminute)
> COMPLEXIFYING 216
> SIMPLIFYING 210
> BLENDED 170
> 
> Is this to process a constant number of generations, or to achieve a
> certain fitness against the hand coded opponents?

Our runs were performed for a set number of generations.  In this 
case, 200 individuals were evolved for 200 generations.  As we note 
in the paper, there is some randomness in the game play of our hand-
coded players, so there is some variation in the lengths of games.  
But since so many games were played each generation, the variation 
should average out over the run.

Note that the Blended runs averaged a little under 3 hours each, 
while the Complexifying runs averaged about 46 minutes longer.  I 
think Colin mentioned having complexifying, then simplifying phases, 
but I think our paper suggests that this would be less efficient than 
searching with both dynamics as you go.  When the average complexity 
gets larger and larger, its going to bog down your system resources.  
The Blended approach keeps the average complexity smaller to begin 
with, which is probably more efficient than bloating and trimming.  
That said, it would be interesting to see someone verify this.

Derek
